title: 105_s2251
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lackawanna Valley American Heritage Area Act of 1998". Congress finds that the industrial and cultural heritage of northeastern Pennsylvania, specifically Lackawanna County, Luzerne County, Wayne County, and Susquehanna County, related to anthracite and related industries is nationally significant. This includes anthracite mining, ironmaking, textiles, and rail transportation, as well as the social history and living cultural traditions of the region. The labor movement in this area also played a significant role in the nation's development. The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for protecting historical and cultural resources in the region, working with various entities to conserve and interpret this heritage for future generations. The Lackawanna Valley American Heritage Area aims to foster relationships among government, private sector, and communities in northeastern Pennsylvania to conserve heritage and pursue economic opportunities. The Lackawanna Heritage Valley Authority would manage the Heritage Area in the 4-county region, focusing on historical, cultural, natural, and recreational resources. The Lackawanna Valley American Heritage Area, managed by the Lackawanna Heritage Valley Authority, defines key terms such as "Heritage Area," "management entity," "management plan," "partner," and "Secretary" in the Act. The Lackawanna Valley American Heritage Area is established, encompassing parts of Lackawanna, Luzerne, Wayne, and Susquehanna counties in Pennsylvania. The Lackawanna Heritage Valley Authority will serve as the management entity for the Heritage Area. The Secretary will enter into a compact with the management entity for the Lackawanna Valley American Heritage Area, outlining objectives, boundaries, goals, conservation approach, and protection measures. The management entity will have authorities and duties for the Heritage Area. The management entity for the Lackawanna Valley American Heritage Area has the authority to use funds for loans, grants, cooperative agreements, and staff compensation. They are required to develop a comprehensive management plan that considers various plans and involves residents, public agencies, and private organizations. The management plan for the Heritage Area must involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include actions to protect the resources. It should specify funding sources and include an inventory of resources in the area that need preservation or development. The management plan for the Heritage Area involves recommendations for resource management, including land and water techniques, intergovernmental agreements, restoration, and construction plans for preservation and development. The management plan for the Heritage Area includes specific commitments of partners for the first 5 years, coordination of local, State, and Federal programs, and an interpretation plan. The management entity must submit the plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in action by the Secretary. The management entity must prioritize implementing actions from the management plan, including assisting in preserving the Heritage Area, establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational resources, and increasing public awareness. The management entity must prioritize implementing actions from the management plan, including increasing public awareness, restoring historic buildings, encouraging economic viability, promoting land use policies, and assisting in placing signs throughout the Heritage Area. The management entity must consider the interests of various groups, hold quarterly public meetings, seek approval for substantial plan amendments, and submit annual reports on accomplishments, expenses, and loans received. The management entity must provide records of loans and grants made, allow audits of expenditure records, and ensure receiving organizations make their expenditure records available for audit. Federal funds received under the Act cannot be used to acquire real property, but the entity can use funds from other sources. The management entity is restricted from using Federal funds obtained through sources other than this Act for authorized purposes. SEC. 7. DUTIES AND AUTHORITIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the management entity for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing actions that conserve historical, cultural, and natural resources and provide educational and recreational opportunities in the Heritage Area. To further the purposes of the Heritage Area, the Secretary may use Federal funds on non-federally owned property for the appropriate treatment of historic sites. The Historic American Buildings Survey/Historic American Engineering Record will conduct necessary studies on the industrial, engineering, building, and architectural history of the Heritage Area. Approval and disapproval of management plans are also outlined. Approval and disapproval of management plans must be done within 90 days of submission. If a plan is disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and recommendations for revisions. Amendments to the plan must also be approved within 90 days of submission. The Secretary must review substantial amendments to the management plan for the Heritage Area and approve them before funds can be used for implementation. The Secretary will not provide grants or assistance under this Act after September 30, 2012. $10,000,000 is authorized for this Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Federal share of costs for activities under this Act cannot exceed 50 percent.
